ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned a lot about the benefits and challenges of immersive journalism. I got to develop more skills as a journalist, in building relationships, interviewing, and writing.

I learned not only about what makes writing good, but also how authors think through everything from who they interview to how they describe the spaces they occupy. I can't even begin to convey how much I've learned from Professor Hobbs' class in a course reviewI really hope he teaches it again! It was the best!

I gained opportunities to practice my non-fiction writing through reading and discussing immersive journalism works, as well as some writing that culminated in a nearly 5000-word length piece. I practiced interviewing skills and received length notes and editing suggestions to improve my writing.
I learned about how to report and write an intensive multi-week journalism piece.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Jeff is the greatest part of this class by far. What a lovely human, professor, and writer. I hope Yale continues inviting his back over and over again. The readings were also great and the opportunity to work on one story for this long is very valuable.

The biggest strength of this class was Professor Hobbs. He made the class interesting for everyone from student journalists to people new to writing. He was always available to meet and always followed up with detailed, nuanced emails that contained further thoughts and musings after our conversations. No improvements necessaryit was seriously perfect!!

Strengths: Professor Hobbs was one of the nicest and welcoming professors I ever had. He was extremely communicative and frequently checked in on my progress while also being very understanding about setbacks and busy schedules.

Weaknesses: The writing/workload was quite backheavy and perhaps more work could have been added earlier.

Strengths: wonderful teacher, great final assignment, incisive feedback, strong readings.
Weaknesses: No workshop component in class, deadlines were perhaps too relaxed, discussions could be more focused on text.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES! Jeff is the very best, you get a unique opportunity to work on a story for a long time, and some great readings to discuss as examples.

Our Monday afternoons were truly the joy of my yearthis is the #1 class you should take at Yale! Professor Hobbs' class made me fall in love with writing again (I seriously can't imagine a better reason to take a class). I really hope he teaches it again so that other students can experience his passion, support, and talent.

Yes! I took this course with limited experience in a proper English/writing class at Yale and found this to be a wonderful experience learning from both peers and students who were more experienced in the field. I think working on a proper months-long project is an amazing opportunity that this course facilitates and Prof. Hobbs is an excellent guide along the way.
Certainly. You grow as a writer and get to learn from one of the best in the field.
